From the two classic approaches, it can be known that if attribute values across alternatives of an attribute are all equal, a small weight will be assigned to it, because such attribute does not help in distinguishing alternatives.

In another word, such an attribute should be assigned a very small weight. Assuming there is (n + 1)th attribute that has all equal attribute values, the decision matrix $$ B $$ becomes $$ B^{*} = [b^{*}_{ij}]_{m \times (n+1)} $$, and the element new column are all $$ \frac{1}{m} $$, i.e $$ b_{i, n+1} = \frac{1}{m} $$.

The existence of the (n + 1)th attribute doesn't affect the decision result of the first n attributes. If choosing the (n + 1)th attribute as reference and assigning 0 to its weight, the dispersion of each attribute of B can be measured by the angle between it and the reference attribute. The larger angle it has, the more important attribute is. The angle between the $$j-th$$ attribute and the reference attribute is:
$$ u_j = \text{arccos } ( \frac{\sum^{m}_{i=1} \frac{b_{ij}}{m} }{ \sqrt{\sum^{m}_{i=1}} (b_{ij})^{2} \sqrt{\sum^{m}_{i=1} (\frac{1}{m})^{2} } } ) $$
Then the angle weight for the $$ j-th $$ attribute is:
$$ w_j = \frac{u_j}{\sum^{n}_{j=1} u_j} $$
**Crisp variant**

The Criterion Impact LOSs (CILOS) method which is another promising approach to determining the objective weights, considers the significance (impact) loss of each criterion, when one of other criteria obtains the optimal largest or smallest value.
First, the minimized criteria are transformed into the maximized ones, so that a criterion's largest value is optimal (best), using:
$$ \bar{r}_{ij} = \frac{\text{min}_{i} r_{ij}}{r_{ij}} $$

The values of the maximized criteria require no transformation. The new matrix will be $$ X = || x_{ij} || $$. Now, the highest values of each criterion in the matrix, i.e., each column, are calculated:
$$ x_j = \text{max}_{i} x_{ij} = x_{k_{j}j} $$
where $$ k_j $$ is the number of the row of $$ j-th $$ column, where the largest value is obtained.
The matrix of the relative loss $$ P = || p_{ij} || $$ is formed as:
$$ p_{ij} = \frac{x_j - a_{ij}}{x_j} = \frac{a_{ii} - a_{ij}}{a_{ii}} $$
The elements pij in the CILOS matrix $$ P $$ show the relative loss of the $$ j-th $$ criterion, if the $$ i-th $$ criterion is selected to be the best.
The $$ F $$ matrix is then determined as:
$$ F = P - diag(\sum^{m}_{ij} p_{ij}) $$
Then, construct an orthonormal basis $$ q $$ for the null space of $$ F $$ matrix.
The last step is to normalize the obtained values:
**Crisp variant**

CRiteria Importance Through Inter-criteria Correlation (CRITIC) method aims at the determination of objective weights of relative importance in Multi-Criteria Decision Making problems. The weights derived incorporate both contrast intensity and conflict which are contained in the structure of the decision problem. The method developed is based on the analytical investigation of the evaluation matrix for extracting all information contained in the evaluation criteria.
The first step requires to normalize the decision matrix with:

where $$ f_j $$ represents every criterion, $$ f_{j}^{*} $$ represents the ideal value which is the best performance in criterion $$ j $$, and $$ f_{j^{*}} $$ stands for the anti-ideal value, which is the worst performance in criterion $$ j $$.

Then, the the amount of information $$ C_j $$, emitted by the $$ j-th $$ criterion can be determined by composing the measures which quantify the two notions through the following multiplicative aggregation formula:
$$ C_j = \sigma_j \times \sum^{m}_{k=1} (1 - r_{jk}) $$
where $$ \sigma_j $$ represents the standard deviation of $$ x_j $$, and $$ r_{jk} $$ represents the linear correlation coefficient between the vectors $$ x_j $$ and $$ x_k $$.

According to the previous analysis, the higher the value $$ C_j $$, the larger the amount of information transmitted by the corresponding criterion and the higher its relative importance for the decision making process. Objective weights result by normalizing these values to unity according to the following equation:
$$ w_j = \frac{C_j}{\sum^{m}_{k=1} C_k} $$
**Crisp variant**

Gini coefficient is used to measure the difference of income allocation quantitatively and investigate comprehensively the internal difference of inhabitant's income allocation as an important International indicator.
The Gini coefficient weighting is an objective weighting method which calculates various indicators of the Gini coefficient as indicators' weights. The weights can be calculated with following steps.
Calculation of the indicator Gini coefficient

Let $$ G_k $$ denote the Gini coefficient of the $$ k^{th} $$ index, let $$ Y_{ki} $$ denote the $$ k^{th} $$ index and the $$ i^{th} $$ data, let $$ n $$ denote the number of the data, let $$ \mu_k $$ denote the expectation of the $$ k^{th} $$ index about all the data. The Gini coefficient of the $$ k^{th} $$ indicator $$ G_k $$ is defined as:
The weight calculation of the indicator Gini coefficient

After Gini coefficient $$ G_k $$ of $$ m $$ indicators in the evaluating system are calculated, indicators' weights are determined according to each Gini coefficient. Gini coefficient weights are defined as:
$$ w_j = \frac{G_k}{\sum^{m}_{i=1} G_i} $$
**Crisp variant**

The idea of Integrated Determination of Objective CRIteria Weight (IDOCRIW) method is based on combining the weights of criteria with different significances into a single overall weight. It makes it possible to combine entropy weights $$ W_j $$ and Criterion Impact Loss weights (CILOS) $$ q_j $$ to obtain the aggregate weights $$ w_j $$ for objective assessment of the criteria array structure:
$$ w_j = \frac{q_j \times W_j}{\sum^{m}_{j=1} q_j \times W_j} $$

These weights will show the variation of individual criteria values (a characteristic of entropy), but the significance of the criteria will decrease due to their higher losses compared to those of other criteria.
**Crisp variant**

The MEthod based on the Removal Effects of Criteria (MEREC) method is in the category of objective weighting methods for obtaining criteria weights. The MEREC uses each criterion's removal effect on the performance of alternatives to determine criteria weights. Greater weights are assigned to the criteria that have higher effects on the performances. In this method, we should define a measure for the performances of alternatives first. To identify the effects of removing each criterion, the absolute deviation measure can be used. This measure reflects the difference between the overall alternative's performance and its performance in removing a criterion. The following steps are used to calculate objective weights by MEREC.
Normalize the decision matrix with:
$$ n_{ij} = \frac{\text{min}_k x_{kj}}{x_{ij}} $$ for profit criteria
$$ n_{ij} = \frac{x_{ij}}{\text{max}_k x_{kj}} $$ for cost criteria
Calculate the overall performance of the alternatives $$ S_i $$ as:
Calculate the performance of the alternatives by removing each criterion as:
Compute the summation of absolute deviations with:
Determine the final weights of the criteria as:
$$ w_j = \frac{E_j}{\sum_{k} E_k} $$
**Crisp variant**

The weights for criteria are determined by calculating the standard deviation of data separately for each column representing the criteria in the decision matrix. The criteria weights are calculated as:
$$ \sigma_j = \sqrt{\frac{1}{n} \sum^{n}_{i=1} (z_{ij} - \bar{z}_j)^{2}} $$
where $$ \bar{z}_j $$ is determined as $$ \frac{1}{n} \sum^{n}_{i=1} z_{ij} $$
$$ w_j  = \frac{ \sigma_j \sqrt{1 - R_j}}{\sum^{m}_{k=1} \sigma_k \sqrt{1 - R_k}} $$

where $$ 1 - R_j $$ is root squared to shorten the difference between the largest and the smallest weights. If it is not root square, the difference between the largest and the smallest weights will be bigger
**Crisp variant**
The weights for criteria are determined by calculating the variance of data separately for each column representing the criteria in the decision matrix.
The first step of calculating criteria weights is to normalize the data with:
Then the variance is calculated as:
$$ V_j = \frac{1}{n} \sum^{n}_{i=1} (n_{ij} - \text{mean}(n_{ij}))^{2} $$
The final criteria weights are calculated with:
$$ w_j = \frac{V_j}{\sum^{m}_{i=1} V_j} $$
**Crisp variant**

Following the Additive Ratio ASsessment (ARAS) method assumptions, the value of the utility function, which identifies the composite relative effectiveness of a feasible alternative, is directly proportional to the relative influence of the values and weights of the main criteria considered in the project. The ARAS method is used to evaluate decision alternatives according to the following steps.
**Step 1.** Definition of a decision matrix of dimension $$n \times m$$, where $n$ is the number of alternatives, and $$ m $$ is the number of criteria
**Step 2.** Calculation of the normalized decision matrix.
**Step 3.** Building a decision matrix $$v_{ij}$$ subjected to a weighting and normalization process.
**Step 4.** Determining values of optimality function.
**Step 5.** Calculate the utility degree $$K_i$$.
where $$S_i$$ and $$S_0$$ are the optimality criterion values.
**Triangular Fuzzy variant**

The fuzzy extension of the Additive Ratio Assessment (ARAS) method was presented by Zavadskas et al. It allows for operating in an uncertain environment based on the data represented as TFNs. The main steps of the fuzzy ARAS procedure can be described as follows.

**Step 1.** Determination of the triangular fuzzy decision matrix $$ X $$, which contains $$ m $$ alternatives and $$ n $$ criteria ($$ i = 1, 2, \ldots, m $$ and $$ j = 1, 2, \ldots, n $$), where $$ x_{ij} $$ is represented as Triangular Fuzzy Number ($$ a, m, b $$).
**Step 2.** Determination of the optimal value of each criterion value.

The $$ \tilde{x}_{0j} $$ denotes the optimal value of $$ j $$ criterion (for a profit criteria $$ \tilde{x}_{0j} = \text{max}_i x_{ij} $$, and for a cost criteria $$ \tilde{x}_{0j} = \text{min}_i x_{ij} $$).
**Step 3.** Calculation of the normalized fuzzy decision matrix with:
$$ n_{ij} = \frac{\tilde{x}_{ij}}{\sum^{m}_{i=0} \tilde{x}_{ij}} $$ for profit criteria, and
$$ n_{ij} = \frac{ \frac{1}{\tilde{x}_{ij}} }{ \sum^{m}_{i=0} \frac{1}{\tilde{x}_{ij}}} $$ for cost criteria
**Step 4.** Calculation of the weighted normalized fuzzy decision matrix
$$ wn_{ij} = n_{ij} \times w_j $$
**Step 5.** Determination of the overall performance index for each alternative with:
**Step 6.** Calculation of the defuzzified values of performance index as:
**Step 7.** Determination of the utility degree of each alternative with the formula:
**Crisp variant**

The suggested approach is based on an integrated simple additive weighting and exponentially weighted product model. It can be a compendium of compromise solutions. To solve a Combined Compromise Solution (CoCoSo) decision problem, after determining the alternatives and the related criteria, the following steps are validated
**Step 1.** Definition of a decision matrix of dimension $$n \times m$$, where $$n$$ is the number of alternatives, and $$m$$ is the number of criteria.
**Step 2.** Calculation of the normalized decision matrix.
**Step 3.** Calculation of the weighted sum of the comparison sequence and the total power weight of the comparison sequences for each alternative.
The values of $$S_i$$ are based on the grey relationship generation method.
For $$P_i$$ the values are achieved according to the multiplicative WASPAS setting.
**Step 4.** Computation of the relative weights of alternatives using aggregation strategies. The formulas below can be used to determine the strategies.
The first strategy expresses the average of the sums of WSM and WPM scores.
$$ k_{i a}=\frac{P_{i}+S_{i}}{\sum_{i=1}^{m}\left(P_{i}+S_{i}\right)} $$
The second strategy expresses the sum of WSM and WPM scores over the best.
$$ k_{i b}=\frac{S_{i}}{\min _{i} S_{i}}+\frac{P_{i}}{\min _{i} P_{i}} $$
The third strategy expresses the compromise strategy of WSM and WPM by using the $$\lambda$$ value.
$$ k_{i c}=\frac{\lambda\left(S_{i}\right)+(1-\lambda)\left(P_{i}\right)}{\left(\lambda \max _{i} S_{i}+(1-\lambda) \max _{i} P_{i}\right)} ; \quad 0 \leqslant \lambda \leqslant 1 $$
**Step 5.** Establish the final ranking of alternatives based on $$k_i$$ values defined. The higher the $$k_i$$ value, the higher the ranking.
$$ k_{i}=\left(k_{i a} k_{i b} k_{i c}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}+\frac{1}{3}\left(k_{i a}+k_{i b}+k_{i c}\right) $$
**Triangular Fuzzy variant**

**Step 1.** Determination of the triangular fuzzy decision matrix $$ X $$, which contains $$ m $$ alternatives and $$ n $$ criteria ($$ i = 1, 2, \ldots, m $$ and $$ j = 1, 2, \ldots, n $$), where $$ x_{ij} $$ is represented as Triangular Fuzzy Number ($$ a, m, b $$).
**Step 2.** Calculate the fuzzy normalized decision matrix. Fot the profit criteria, the following formula can be used:
$$ n_{ij} = \frac{max(b_{j}) - a_{ij}}{max(b_{j}) - min(a_{j})}, \frac{max(b_{j}) - m_{ij}}{max(b_{j}) - min(a_{j})}, \frac{max(b_{j}) - b_{j}}{max(b_{j}) - min(a_{j})} $$
and for the cost criteria as:
$$ n_{ij} = \frac{a_{ij} - min(a_{j})}{max(b_{j}) - min(a_{j})}, \frac{m_{ij} - min(a_{j})}{max(b_{j}) - min(a_{j})}, \frac{b_{j} - min(a_{j})}{max(b_{j}) - min(a_{j})} $$
**Step 3.** The fuzzy sum of the weighted comparability and the power weight of the comparability sequences for each alternative are computed as follows:
$$ S_i =  \sum^{n}_{j=1} w^a_j n^a_ij, \sum^{n}_{j=1} w^m_j n^m_ij, \sum^{n}_{j=1} w^b_j n^b_ij $$
**Step 4.** Three aggregation strategies are applied to obtain three fuzzy appraisal scores:
1: $$ f_{ia} = \frac{P_i^a + S_i^a}{\sum^{m}_{i=1} P_i^b + S_i^b}, \frac{P_i^m + S_i^m}{\sum^{m}_{i=1} P_i^m + S_i^m}, \frac{P_i^b + S_i^b}{\sum^{m}_{i=1} P_i^a + S_i^a}  $$
2: $$ f_{im} = \frac{S_i^a}{min(S_i^a)} + \frac{P_i^a}{min(P_i^a)}, \frac{S_i^m}{min(S_i^a)} + \frac{P_i^m}{min(P_i^a)}, \frac{S_i^b}{min(S_i^a)} + \frac{P_i^b}{min(P_i^a)} $$

3: $$ f_{ib} = \frac{\lambda(S_i^a) + (1 - \lambda)(P_i^a)}{\lambda max(S_i^b) + (1 - \lambda) max(P_i^b)}, \frac{\lambda(S_i^m) + (1 - \lambda)(P_i^m)}{\lambda max(S_i^b) + (1 - \lambda) max(P_i^b)}, \frac{\lambda(S_i^b) + (1 - \lambda)(P_i^b)}{\lambda max(S_i^b) + (1 - \lambda) max(P_i^b)}  $$
where $$ \lambda $$ is usually taken as 0.5 and this value is determined by the decision-maker
**Step 5.** The fuzzy appraisal scores are converted into crisp appraisal scores as:
$$ f_{ia} = \frac{f_{ia}^a + f_{ia}^m + f_{ia}^b}{3} $$
$$ f_{im} = \frac{f_{im}^a + f_{im}^m + f_{im}^b}{3} $$
$$ f_{ib} = \frac{f_{ib}^a + f_{ib}^m + f_{ib}^b}{3} $$
**Step 6.** The crisp appraisal scores are combined to obtain the final score for each alternative as:
The alternative with the highest score is the best alternative
**Crisp variant**

In COmbinative Distance-based ASsessment (CODAS) method, the desirability of alternatives is determined by using two measures. The main and primary measure are related to the Euclidean distance of alternatives from the negative-ideal. Using this type of distance requires an -norm indifference space for criteria. The secondary measure is the Taxicab distance, which is related to the -norm indifference space. Clearly, the alternative which has greater distances from the negative-ideal solution is more desirable. In this method, if two alternatives are incomparable according to the Euclidean distance, then the Taxicab distance is used as secondary measure. Although the -norm indifference space is preferred in the CODAS, two types of indifference space could be considered in its process. Based on the assumption that alternatives and criteria are available, the steps of the proposed method can then be presented as follows:
**Step 1.** Construct the decision making matrix $$ X $$,
where $$ x_{ij} $$ denotes the performance value of $$i-th$$ alternative on $$j-th$$ criterion
**Step 2.** Calculate the normalized decision matrix. Linear normalization of performance values is used as given by:
$$ n_{ij} = \frac{x_{ij}}{max_i x_{ij}} $$ if $$ j \in N_b$$
$$ n_{ij} = \frac{min_i x_{ij}}{x_{ij}} $$ if $$ j \in N_c$$
where $$ N_b $$ and $$ N_c $$ represents the sets of benefit and cost criteria, respectively.
**Step 3.** Calculate the weighted normalized decision matrix. The weighted normalized performance values are calculated as given by:
$$ r_{ij} = w_j n_{ij} $$, where $$w_j$$ denotes the weight of $$j-th$$ criterion
**Step 4.** Determine the negative-ideal solution (point) as:
$$ ns = [ns_j]_{1 \times m} ; ns_j = min_i r_{ij} $$
**Step 5.**  Calculate the Euclidean and Taxicab distances of alternatives from the negative-ideal solution as
**Step 6.**  Construct the relative assessment matrix as
$$ R_{a} = [h_{ik}]_{n \times n} $$
$$ h_{ik} = (E_i - E_k) + (\psi(E_i - E_k) \times (T_i - T_k)) $$
where $$k \in {1, 2, ..., n} $$ and $$\psi$$ denotes threshold function to recognize the equality of the Euclidean.
**Step 7.** Calculate the assessment score of each alternative as given by:
**Step 8.** Rank the alternatives according to the decreasing values of assessment score ($$ H $$). The alternative with the highest $$ H $$ is the best choice among the alternatives.
**Triangular Fuzzy variant**

COmbinative Distance-based ASsessment (CODAS) is a new and influential MCDM tool which has been recently developed by Keshavarz Ghorabaee et al. Under this method, alternatives desirability is based on $$ l^1 $$-norm and $$ l^2 $$-norm indifference spaces for criteria. The desirability of alternatives is based on combined Euclidean and Taxicab distances values from the negative ideal solution. Since, for searching the desirability of alternatives for a problem under fuzzy environment Euclidean and Taxicab distances values can't be used (as defined only for crisp environment) therefore fuzzy weighted Euclidean distance ($$ ED_i $$) and fuzzy weighted Hamming distance ($$ HD_i $$) are used for alternatives selection. Let there are $$ m $$ possible alternatives, $$ n $$ criteria and $$ k $$ decision makers. The main steps involved in fuzzy CODAS approach are as follows:

**Step 1.** Determination of the triangular fuzzy decision matrix $$ X $$, which contains $$ m $$ alternatives and $$ n $$ criteria ($$ i = 1, 2, \ldots, m $$ and $$ j = 1, 2, \ldots, n $$), where $$ x_{ij} $$ is represented as Triangular Fuzzy Number ($$ a, m, b $$).
**Step 2.** Calculate the fuzzy normalized decision matrix. Fot the profit criteria, the following formula can be used:
$$ n_{ij} = \frac{x_{ij}}{\text{max}_i x_{ij}} $$
and for the cost criteria:
$$ n_{ij} = 1 - \frac{x_{ij}}{\text{max}_i x_{ij}} $$
**Step 3.** Compute fuzzy weighted normalized matrix $$ V = [v_{ij}]_{n \times m} $$, where $$ v_{ij} = n_{ij} \times w_j $$
**Step 4.** Tabulate fuzzy negative solution values by using the relation as $$ NS = [ns_j]_{1 \times m} $$, where $$ ns_j = \text{min}_i v_{ij} $$
**Step 5.** Compute $$ ED_i $$ and $$ HD_i $$ distances for each alternative from fuzzy negative solution value by using:
$$ ED_i = \sum^{m}_{j=1} E_d (v_{ij}, ns_j) $$
$$ HD_i = \sum^{m}_{j=1} H_d (v_{ij}, ns_j) $$
**Step 6.** Establish relative assessment matrix as $$ RA = [p_{ik}]_{n \times n} $$, where $$ p_{ik} = (ED_i - ED_k) + (t(ED_i - ED_k)) \times (HD_i - HD_k) $$
The $$ t $$ represents a threshold function that can be represented by:
$$ 1 \quad if |x| \geq \emptyset $$
$$ 0 \quad if |x| < \emptyset $$
where $$ \emptyset $$ is threshold parameter of the function and its value is to be set by the decision maker in the range of 0.01 - 0.05
**Step 7.** Compute the assessment score for each alternative with:
**Crisp variant**

The Characteristic Objects Method (COMET) method stands out from other MCDA methods in that it is completely free of ranking reversal phenomenon. It allows for creating a multi-criteria decision analysis model, which will serve unequivocal results regardless of the number of alternatives used in the system. Below main steps of the method are described.

**Step 1.** Define the Space of the Problem - the expert determines the dimensionality of the problem by selecting the number $$r$$ of criteria, $$C_1, C_2, ..., C_r$$. Then, the set of fuzzy numbers for each criterion $$C_i$$ is selected.
$$ C_r = \{\tilde{C}_{r1}, \tilde{C}_{r2}, ..., \tilde{C}_{rc_r}\} $$
where $$C_1,C_2,...,C_r$$ are numbers of the fuzzy numbers for all criteria.
**Step 2.** Generate Characteristic Objects - The Characteristic Objects ($$CO$$) are obtained by using the Cartesian Product of fuzzy numbers cores for each criteria.
$$ CO = C(C_1) \times C(C_2) \times ... \times C(C_r) $$

**Step 3.** Rank the Characteristic Objects - the expert determines the Matrix of Expert Judgment ($$MEJ$$). It is a result of pairwise comparison of the COs by the problem expert. The $$MEJ$$ matrix contains results of comparing Characteristic Objects by the expert, where $$\alpha_{ij}$$ is the result of comparing $$CO_i$$ and $$CO_j$$ by the expert. The function $$f_{exp}$$ denotes the mental function of the expert. It depends solely on the knowledge of the expert.
$$ 0.0, f_{exp}(CO_i) < f_{exp}(CO_j) $$
$$ 0.5, f_{exp}(CO_i) = f_{exp}(CO_j) $$
$$ 1.0, f_{exp}(CO_i) > f_{exp}(CO_j) $$
Afterwards, the vertical vector of the Summed Judgments ($$SJ$$) is obtained.
$$ SJ_i=\sum^{t}_{j=1}\alpha_{ij} $$
Values of preference are approximated for each $$CO$$. As a result, the vertical vector $$P$$ is obtained, where $$i-th$$ row contains the approximate value of preference for $$CO_i$$.
**Step 4.** The Rule Base - each Characteristic Object and value of preference is converted to a fuzzy rule.
IF $$C(\tilde{C}_{1i})$$ AND $$C(\tilde{C}_{2i})$$ AND ... THEN $$P_i$$

**Step 5.** Inference and Final Ranking - each alternative is presented as a set of crisp numbers (e.g., $$A_i=\{a_{1i}, a_{2i}, ..., a_{ri}\}$$). This set corresponds to criteria $$C_1, C_2, ..., C_r$$. Mamdani's fuzzy inference method is used to compute preference of $$i-th$$ alternative. The rule base guarantees that the obtained results are unequivocal. The bijection makes the COMET a completely rank reversal free.
**Crisp variant**

The COmplex PRoportional ASsessment (COPRAS) was introduced by Zavadskas. This approach assumes a direct and proportional relationship of the importance of investigated variants on a system of criteria adequately describing the decision variants and on values and weights of the criteria. This method ranks alternatives based on their relative importance (weight). Final ranking is creating using the positive and negative ideal solutions. Assuming, that we have a decision matrix with m alternatives and n criteria is represented as $$ X $$ , the COPRAS method is defined in five steps:
**Step 1.** Calculate the normalized decision matrix using:
**Step 2.** Calculate the weighted normalized decision matrix, which represents a multiplication of the normalized decision matrix elements with the appropriate weight coefficients using:
$$ v_{ij} = r_{ij} \times w_j $$
**Step 3.** Determine the sums of weighted normalized values, which was calculated previously with:
$$ S_{+i} = \sum^{k}_{j=1} v_{ij} $$, if criterion $$ j $$ is profit
$$ S_{-i} = \sum^{m}_{j=k+1} v_{ij} $$, if criterion $$ j $$ is cost
**Step 4.** Calculate the relative significance of alternatives using:
$$ Q_i = S_{+i} + \frac{ S_{-min} \times \sum^{m}_{i=1} S_{-i}}{ S_{-i} \times \sum^{m}_{i=1} (\frac{S_{-min}}{S_{-i}}) } $$
**Step 5.** Final ranking is performed according $$ U_i $$ values with:
$$ U_i = \frac{Q_i}{Q^{max}_{i}} \times 100%  $$
**Triangular Fuzzy variant**

**Crisp variant**

The best alternative in the Evaluation based on Distance from Average Solution (EDAS) method is corresponded to the distance from average solution (AV). In this method, two first measures are delivered as the positive distance from average (PDA), and the negative distance from average (NDA). These measures can show the difference between each solution (alternative) and the average solution. Therefore, higher values of PDA and lower values of NDA will indicate optimal solution. In fact, the higher values of PDA and/or lower values of NDA represent that the solution (alternative) is better than average solution. Classical algorithm of EDAS can be followed using the following steps.
**Step 1.**  Initial decision matrix $$ X $$ is expected to be constructed by real data or using decision-makers.
**Step 2.** Average solution for each criterion is calculated based on:
$$ AV = [AV_j]_{1 \times m} $$
$$ AV_j = \frac{\sum^{n}_{i=1} X_{ij}}{n} $$
**Step 3.** Positive distance from average (PDA) and negative distance from average (NDA) are calculated:
$$ PDA = [PDA_{ij}]_{n \times m} $$
$$ NDA = [NDA_{ij}]_{n \times m} $$
If criterion is type of profit, the PDA and NDA are calculated as:
$$ PDA_{ij} = \frac{max (0, (X_{ij} - AV_j))}{AV_j} $$
$$ NDA_{ij} = \frac{max (0, (AV_j - X_{ij}))}{AV_j} $$
If criterion is type of cost, the PDA and NDA are calculated as:
$$ PDA_{ij} = \frac{max (0, ( AV_j - X_{ij}))}{AV_j} $$
$$ NDA_{ij} = \frac{max (0, (X_{ij} - AV_j))}{AV_j} $$
**Step 4.** Calculate the weighted sum of PDA and NDA for all alternatives using:
$$ SP_i = \sum^{m}_{j=1} w_j \times PDA_{ij} $$
$$ SN_i = \sum^{m}_{j=1} w_j \times NDA_{ij} $$
**Step 5.** Normalization of the obtained values using:
$$ NSP_i = \frac{SP_i}{max_i SP_i}  $$
$$ NSN_i = 1 - \frac{SN_i}{max_i SN_i}  $$
**Step 6.** Finally, appraisal score (AS) for each alternative is calculated based on:
$$ AS_i = \frac{1}{2} (NSP_i + NSN_i) $$
**Triangular Fuzzy variant**

The Evaluation based on Distance from Average Solution (EDAS) method was proposed by Ghorabaee et al. Its functioning is based on the calculation of the positive distance from average (PDA) and negative distance from average (NDA). The decision variants characterized by higher PDA values and lower NDA values are preferable. The triangular fuzzy number extension of the standard EDAS method enables it to operate in the fuzzy environment where uncertain data appear. Main steps of the method are defined as follows.

**Step 1.** Determination of the triangular fuzzy decision matrix $$ X $$, which contains $$ m $$ alternatives and $$ n $$ criteria ($$ i = 1, 2, \ldots, m $$ and $$ j = 1, 2, \ldots, n $$), where $$ x_{ij} $$ is represented as Triangular Fuzzy Number ($$ a, m, b $$).
**Step 2.** Determination of the average triangular fuzzy decision matrix based on the initial triangular fuzzy decision matrix as:
$$ AV_j = \frac{\sum^{n}_{i=1} x_{ij}}{n} $$

**Step 3.** Calculation of the fuzzy Positive Distance from Average (PDA) and fuzzy Negative Distance from Average (NDA). The calculation uses $$ k $$ function which represents the defuzzification method. Calculations for profit criteria can be performed as:
$$ PDA_{ij} = \frac{\psi(x_{ij} - AV_j)}{k(AV_j)} $$
$$ NDA_{ij} = \frac{\psi(AV_j - x_{ij})}{k(AV_j)} $$
and for cost criteria as:
$$ PDA_{ij} = \frac{\psi(AV_j - x_{ij})}{k(AV_j)} $$
$$ NDA_{ij} = \frac{\psi(x_{ij} - AV_j)}{k(AV_j)} $$
**Step 4.** Calculation of the fuzzy weighted positive (SP) and negative (SN) distances with:
$$ SP_i = \sum^{m}_{j=1} ( w_j + PDA_{ij}) $$
$$ SN_i = \sum^{m}_{j=1} ( w_j + NDA_{ij}) $$
**Step 5.** Determination of the normalized fuzzy weighted positive (NSP) and negative (NSN) distances as:
$$ NSP_i = \frac{SP_i}{\text{max}_i (k(SP_i))} $$
$$ NSN_i = 1 - \frac{SN_i}{\text{max}_i (k(SN_i))} $$
**Step 6.** Calculation of the fuzzy Appraisal Score (AS) for each alternative with:
$$ AS_i = \frac{NSP_i + NSN_i}{2} $$
**Crisp variant**

The summation of gaps for each criterion gives the total gap for every observed alternative. At the end, it comes to the alternatives ranking, where the best ranked alternative is the one with the smallest value for the total gap. The alternative with the smallest value for the total gap is the alternative which had values closest to the ideal weights according to the largest number of criteria (ideal criteria values). The MAIRCA method is conducted in 6 steps.

In fact, he does not have preference to any of the proposed alternatives. The main assumption is that decision-maker does not take into account the probabilities of any alternative selection. The decision-maker perceives the alternatives as if any of them can have equal probability of appearance, so the preference to choose one of them from m possible alternatives is:

**Step 5.** The calculation of the total gap matrix $$ G $$. The elements of the matrix $$ G $$ are calculated as the difference (gap) between theoretical $$ t_{pij} $$ and real evaluations $$ t_{rij} $$, or by actually subtracting the elements of the theoretical evaluation matrix $$ T_p $$ with the elements of the real evaluation matrix $$ T_r $$.
Gap $$ g_{ij} $$ takes values from the interval $$ g_{ij} \in [0, (t_{pij} - t_{rij})] $$, according to:

The Measurement Alternatives and Ranking according to COmpromise Solution (MARCOS) method is based on defining the relationship between alternatives and reference values (ideal and anti-ideal alternatives). On the basis of the defined relationships, the utility functions of alternatives are determined and compromise ranking is made in relation to ideal and anti-ideal solutions. Decision preferences are defined on the basis of utility functions. Utility functions represent the position of an alternative with regard to an ideal and anti-ideal solution. The best alternative is the one that is closest to the ideal and at the same time furthest from the anti-ideal reference point. The MARCOS method is performed through the following steps:
**Step 1.** Formation of an initial decision-making matrix $$ X $$. Multi-criteria models include the definition of a set of $$ n $$ criteria and $$ m $$ alternatives.
**Step 2.** Formation of an extended initial matrix. In this step, the extension of the initial matrix is performed by defining the ideal ($$ AI $$) and anti-ideal ($$ AAI $$) solution:
$$ AAI = min_i x_{ij} $$ if criterion $$ j $$ is profit, and $$ max_{i} x_{ij} $$ if criterion $$ j $$ is cost
$$ AI = max_i x_{ij} $$ if criterion $$ j $$ is profit, and $$ min_{i} x_{ij} $$ if criterion $$ j $$ is cost
**Step 3.** Normalization of the extended initial matrix $$ X $$. The elements of the normalized matrix $$ N = [n_{ij}]_{m \times n} $$ are obtained by applying:
$$ n_{ij} = \frac{x_{ai}}{x_{ij}} $$ if criterion $$ j $$ is cost
$$ n_{ij} = \frac{x_{ij}}{x_{ai}} $$ if criterion $$ j $$ is profit

**Step 4.**: Determination of the weighted matrix $$ V = [v_{ij}]_{m \times n} $$. The weighted matrix $$ V $$ is obtained by multiplying the normalized matrix $$ N $$ with the weight coefficients of the criterion $$ w_j $$ as:
$$ v_{ij} = n_{ij} \times w_j $$
**Step 5.** Calculation of the utility degree of alternatives $$ K_i $$. The utility degrees of an alternative in relation to the anti-ideal and ideal solution are calculated as:
and the $$ S_i $$ is calculated as $$ S_{i} = \sum^{n}_{i=1} v_{ij} $$

**Step 6.** Determination of the utility function of alternatives $$ f (K_i) $$. The utility function is the compromise of the observed alternative in relation to the ideal and anti-ideal solution. The utility function of alternatives is defined by:

**Step 7.** Ranking the alternatives. Ranking of the alternatives is based on the final values of utility functions. It is desirable that an alternative has the highest possible value of the utility function.

**Step 1.** Determination of the triangular fuzzy decision matrix $$ X $$, which contains $$ m $$ alternatives and $$ n $$ criteria ($$ i = 1, 2, \ldots, m $$ and $$ j = 1, 2, \ldots, n $$), where $$ x_{ij} $$ is represented as Triangular Fuzzy Number ($$ a, m, b $$).

$$ s^{+m}_{i} = \sum^{n}_{j=1} v^m_{ij} \quad | \quad j \in J^{\text{max}} $$
$$ s^{+b}_{i} = \sum^{n}_{j=1} v^b_{ij} \quad | \quad j \in J^{\text{max}} $$
On the other hand, for non-beneficial criteria, the overall ratings of an alternative are calculated as follows:
$$ s^{-a}_{i} = \sum^{n}_{j=1} v^a_{ij} \quad | \quad j \in J^{\text{min}} $$
$$ s^{-m}_{i} = \sum^{n}_{j=1} v^m_{ij} \quad | \quad j \in J^{\text{min}} $$
$$ s^{-b}_{i} = \sum^{n}_{j=1} v^b_{ij} \quad | \quad j \in J^{\text{min}} $$

**Step 5.** Determine the overall performance index (Si) for each alternative. For this, the defuzzified values of the overall ratings for beneficial and non-beneficial criteria for each alternative are computed using the vertex method as:

**Step 6.** Based on the descending values of overall performance index, rank the alternatives from the best to the worst. The alternative with the highest overall performance index is the most favorable choice.

The Operational Competitiveness Ratings (OCRA) is MCDM method to measure the relative performance (efficiency) of a set of production units (competitive alternatives). The main idea of the OCRA method is to perform the evaluation of alternatives with respect to beneficial and non-beneficial criteria and finally to obtain the final ranking by combining these two sets of ratings. This method uses an intuitive method for incorporating the decision makers preferences as the relative importance of the criteria

**Step 1.** The decision matrix $$ X $$ is formed. Alternatives and criteria are listed in the row and column of the decision matrix respectively. The decision matrix shows the performance of different alternatives with respect to various criteria.

**Step 2.** Preference ratings with respect to the non-beneficial or input criteria are computed. In this step, the scores that various alternatives receive for the non-beneficial criteria are only taken into account. The aggregate performance of $$ i-th $$ alternative with respect to all non-beneficial criteria ($$ \bar{I_i} $$) is calculated using:
$$ \bar{I_i} = \sum^{g}_{j=1} w_j \frac{max (x_{ij}) - x_{ij}}{min (x_{ij})} $$

where $$ g $$ is the number of non-beneficial criteria and $$ w_j $$ is the relative importance of $$ j-th $$ criterion (calibration constant). $$ w_j $$ issued to increase or decrease the impact of the difference on the rating ($$ \bar{I_i} $$) with respect to $$ j-th $$ criterion.
**Step 3.** For each alternative the linear preference rating for the non-beneficial criteria ($$ \bar{I_i} $$) is calculated as:
$$ \bar{\bar{I_i}} = \bar{I_i} - min(\bar{I_i})  $$

**Step 4.** The preference ratings with respect to the beneficial or output criteria are computed. The aggregate performance for $$ i-th $$ alternative on all the beneficial criteria ($$ O_i$$ ) is measured by:
$$ \bar{O_i} = \sum^{n}_{j=g+1} w_j \frac{x_{ij} - min(x_{ij})}{min(x_{ij})}  $$
where $$ (n - g) $$ is the number of beneficial criteria and $$ w_j $$ is the relative importance of $$ j-th $$ criterion.
**Step 5.** The linear preference rating for the beneficial criteria is calculated as :
$$ \bar{\bar{O_i}} = \bar{O_i} - min(\bar{O_i})  $$

**Step 6.** The overall preference rating for each alternative is calculated by scaling the sum of $$ \bar{\bar{I_i}} $$ and $$ \bar{\bar{O_i}} $$ so that the least preferable alternative receives a rating of zero. The overall preference rating of $$ i-th $$ alternative ($$ P_i $$) is calculated as :
$$ P_i = ( \bar{\bar{I_i}} + \bar{\bar{O_i}} ) - min ( \bar{\bar{I}} + \bar{\bar{O}} ) $$
**Triangular Fuzzy variant**
The Fuzzy Operational Competitiveness Ratings (OCRA) method consists of seven steps defined as follows.

**Step 1.** Determination of the triangular fuzzy decision matrix $$ X $$, which contains $$ m $$ alternatives and $$ n $$ criteria ($$ i = 1, 2, \ldots, m $$ and $$ j = 1, 2, \ldots, n $$), where $$ x_{ij} $$ is represented as Triangular Fuzzy Number ($$ a, m, b $$).
**Step 2.** Calculation of fuzzy performance ratings in accordance with non-beneficial criteria are aggregated as:
$$ I_s = \sum_{i \in \Omega_{\text{min}}} w^{*}_i \frac{\text{max}_i x_{si} - x_{si}}{\text{min}_i x_{si}} $$
where $$ I_s $$ represents the aggregate fuzzy performance rating of the $$ s-th $$ alternative calculated based on the non-beneficial criteria
**Step 3.** Calculation of fuzzy linear performance rating of each alternative considered the non-beneficial criteria are evaluated by:
$$ \bar{I_s} = I_s - \text{min}_s I_s $$
**Step 4.**  Calculation of fuzzy performance ratings for the beneficial criteria are aggregated using:
$$ O_s = \sum_{i \in \Omega_{\text{max}}} w^{*}_i \frac{x_{si} - \text{min}_i x_{si}}{\text{min}_i x_{si}} $$
where $$ O_s $$ is the aggregate fuzzy performance rating of the $$ s-th $$ alternative calculated based on the beneficial criteria
**Step 5.** Calculation of fuzzy linear performance rating of each alternative in accordance with the beneficial criteria are calculated by:
$$ \bar{O_s} = O_s - \text{min}_s O_s $$
**Step 6.** Calculation of fuzzy overall performance rating for each alternative is obtained by:
$$ P_s = \bar{I_s} + \bar{O_s} - \text{min} (\bar{I_s} + \bar{O_s}) $$
where $$ P_s $$ denotes fuzzy overall performance rating of $$ s-th $$ alternative.

**Step 7.** : In the last step, fuzzy overall performance ratings are converted into crisp overall performance ratings ($$ P_s $$). After obtaining crisp overall performance ratings, alternatives are ranked with respect to these ratings. Alternative having the highest rating is selected as the most appropriate alternative.
**Crisp variant**

and for the $$ S_{i(\text { neg-ideal })} $$

Positive-ideal distance for sPROBID:

The Technique for Order Preference by Similarity to an Ideal Solution (TOPSIS) method was developed in 1981 by Chen and Hwang. This technique determines each decision variant's distance to the Positive Ideal Solution (PIS) and Negative Ideal Solution (NIS). Based on them, the preference of alternatives is being calculated. Two types of criteria can be identified while performing the normalization step. Profit type means that greater values are preferred. On the other hand, cost type is assigned to factors for which lower values are more favorable. To present the formal notation of the method, main steps should be introduced.
**Step 1.** Determination of the decision matrix ($$X$$) in the multi-criteria problem.
**Step 2.** Normalization of the defined decision matrix $$X$$.
For profit: $$ r_{i j}=\frac{x_{i j}-\min _{j}\left(x_{i j}\right)}{\max _{j}\left(x_{i j}\right)-\min _{j}\left(x_{i j}\right)} $$
For cost: $$ r_{i j}=\frac{\max x_{j}\left(x_{i j}\right)-x_{i j}}{\max x_{j}\left(x_{i j}\right)-\min _{j}\left(x_{i j}\right)} $$
**Step 3.** Calculation of a weighted normalized decision matrix.
$$ v_{i j}=w_{i} \cdot r_{i j}, \quad i=1, \ldots, m \quad j=1, \ldots, n $$
where the vector of weights $$w$$ meets the requirement of $$\sum_{j=1}^{n} w_j = 1$$, and the number of weights is equal to the number of criteria in the decision matrix.
**Step 4.** Identification of the Positive and Negative Ideal Solutions for a defined decision-making problem.

$$ A_{i}^{*} = \left\{v_{1}^{*}, \ldots, v_{n}^{*}\right\} =\left\{\left(\max _{j} v_{i j} \quad | \quad i \in I^{P}\right),\right. \left.\left(\min _{j} v_{i j} \quad | \quad i \in I^{C}\right)\right\} $$

$$ A_{i}^{-} =\left\{v_{1}^{-}, \ldots, v_{n}^{-}\right\} =\left\{\left(\min _{j} v_{i j} \quad | \quad i \in I^{P}\right),\right. \left.\left(\max _{j} v_{i j} \quad | \quad i \in I^{C}\right)\right\} $$
where $$I^{P}$$ stands for profit type criteria and $$I^{C}$$ for cost type.
**Step 5.** Calculation of the Positive and Negative Distances using the $$n$$-dimensional Euclidean distance.
$$ D_{i}^{*}=\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(v_{i j}-v_{i}^{*}\right)^{2}}, \quad i=1, \ldots, m $$
$$ D_{i}^{-}=\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(v_{i j}-v_{i}^{-}\right)^{2}}, \quad i=1, \ldots, m $$
**Step 6.** Calculation of the relative closeness to the Ideal Solution.
**Triangular Fuzzy variant**

The VIseKriterijumska Optimizacija I Kompromisno Resenje (VIKOR) is a method developed by Opricovic in 1998. It is based on the definition of the vector of weights for the set of criteria considered in the problem. This approach allows for obtaining the closeness to the Ideal Solution ($$IS$$). Based on this distance, the final ranking is determined, assessing the quality of the decision variants. The result obtained may largely depend on the weights for the criteria defined at the initial phase.

**Step 2.** Calculation of the closeness to the Ideal Solution ($$IS$$).

The metric, denoted as $$ WS_{dra} (x, y) $$, is defined as follows:

The metric operates on two rankings, denoted as $$ x $$ and $$ y $$, with each ranking consisting of $$ N $$ elements. The key element of this metric is the function $$ f(x_i, y_i) $$, which compares the elements at corresponding positions in the two rankings. The function $$ f(x_i, y_i) $$ is defined as follows:
$$ f (x_i, y_i) = 1 $$, if $$ x_i \neq y_i $$

In other words, if the elements at position $$ i $$ in the rankings $$ x $$ and $$ y $$ are the same, $$ f(x_i, y_i) $$ is assigned a value of $$ 0 $$. Conversely, if the elements are different, $$ f(x_i, y_i) $$ takes the value of $$ 1 $$.

In statistics, Goodman and Kruskal's gamma is a measure of rank correlation, i.e., the similarity of the orderings of the data when ranked by each of the quantities. It measures the strength of association of the cross tabulated data when both variables are measured at the ordinal level. It makes no adjustment for either table size or ties. Values range from -1 (100% negative association, or perfect inversion) to +1 (100% positive association, or perfect agreement). A value of zero indicates the absence of association.
The estimate of gamma, $$ G $$, depends on two quantities:
$$ N_s $$, the number of pairs of cases ranked in the same order on both variables
$$ N_d $$, the number of pairs of cases ranked in reversed order on both variables
where 'ties' (cases where either of the two variables in the pair are equal) are dropped. Then
$$ G = \frac{N_s - N_d}{N_s + N_d} $$
This statistic can be regarded as the maximum likelihood estimator for the theoretical quantity $$ \gamma $$, where
$$ \gamma = \frac{P_s - P_d}{P_s + P_d} $$
and where $$ P_s $$ and $$ P_d $$ are the probabilities that a randomly selected pair of observations will place in the same or opposite order respectively, when ranked by both variables.
Critical values for the gamma statistic are sometimes found by using an approximation, whereby a transformed value, $$ t $$ of the statistic is referred to Student t distribution, where
$$ t \approx G \sqrt{ \frac{N_s + N_d}{n(1-G^{2}} } $$
and where $$ n $$ is the number of observations (not the number of pairs):
$$ n \neq N_s + N_d $$

In statistics, the Kendall rank correlation coefficient, commonly referred to as Kendall's $$ \tau $$ coefficient (after the Greek letter $$ \tau $$, tau), is a statistic used to measure the ordinal association between two measured quantities. A $$ \tau $$ test is a non-parametric hypothesis test for statistical dependence based on the $$ \tau $$ coefficient. It is a measure of rank correlation: the similarity of the orderings of the data when ranked by each of the quantities.
The Tau-a statistic tests the strength of association of the cross tabulations. Both variables have to be ordinal. Tau-a will not make any adjustment for ties. It is defined as:
$$ \tau = \frac{n_c - n_d}{n_0} $$
where
$$ n_c $$ is number of concordant pairs,
$$ n_d $$ is number of discordant pairs,

When preference values calculated for alternatives are to be compared, the Pearson correlation coefficient can be used. Cross-correlation between vectors is used. It is often used when comparing real signals. The formula used to calculate the Pearson correlation coefficient is shown below:
$$ \rho(a, b) = \frac{E(a b)}{\sigma_{a} \sigma_{b}} $$

where $$ \sigma_{a} $$ means preference for alternative $i$ from first method, $$ \sigma_{b} $$ is the preference for alternative $$ i $$ from second method and $$ E $$ is a cross-correlation between $$ a $$ and $$ b $$.

As with the Pearson coefficient, the Spearman correlation coefficient is used when comparing preference values of alternatives. Its use is recommended when not following the normal bivarate distribution of rankings. The calculation of this coefficient is shown below:
$$ r_{s} = 1 - \frac{6 \times \sum d_{i}^{2}}{N \times ( N^{2} - 1 )} $$
where $$ d_i $$ - distance between ranked alternatives in both rankings, $$ N $$ - amount of alternatives.

This weight similarity coefficient assumes that we have two identified vectors of criteria weights, namely $$ w = {w_1, w_2, ..., w_N} $$ and $$ v = {v_1, v_2, ..., v_N} $$. The Manhattan distance between them is then defined as follows:

This allows us to calculate the absolute distance between two vectors of weights. However, it is difficult to determine how similar the two vectors are. A way to normalize the distance is to rely on the minimum value of one of the weight vectors according to the following formula:
$$ WSC = 1 - \frac{d_1 (w, v)}{2 \cdot (1 - min(w))} = 1 - \frac{\sum^{N}_{i=1} | w_i - v_i | }{2 \cdot (1 - min_i w_i)} $$
WSC values are in the range [0, 1], where 1 means that there is no difference between the weights and 0 means a large difference.
